ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The class offers a survey of some of the most influential cultural currents of Renaissance Italy with a strong emphasis upon Florence and Rome. I would recommend the course to any student interested in the early modern period, especially one interested in courtly culture, political thought, and the early Humanist tradition.
I would recommend it to anyone already interested in the period.

HIST 563 is a whirlwind tour of the society and culture of Renaissance Italy. You will be asked to engage critically with both the secondary literature and primary sources on/about the period. I highly recommend the course.
I would recommend the course simply by virtue of having Quint as an instructor.
The course is a broad overview of Renaissance Italy, particularly 15th Century Florence. The course is useful for understanding that place and time as well as the future movements inspired by them.
I definitely would, although it is a challenging course (but in a good way).

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I came away with a clear and specific understanding of some large-scale cultural movements in Italy of which I previously had only a vague knowledge. It was good to get this foundation, even though I don't anticipate that the topics that came up in the class will play a very important role in my dissertation. The class's interdisciplinary focus and integrated approach to the Renaissance enriched my understanding of the period.
It was good to focus on a different geographical region than the one I usually study.
It provided insight into a period I was unfamiliar with. I see little impact on my dissertation/research.
The focus on art history and social history, besides the literary materials, is extremely helpful for me to better understand Italian Renaissance as a whole.

The course material deepened my knowledge of the Renaissance by familiarizing me with works by Lorenzo de Medici and Angelo Poliziano that I had never read despite studying the period for quite a while. Professor Quint also raised fascinating questions about the relationship between humanism and the temporal alienation of modernity.
The course is invaluable background for research in southern and northern renaissance culture. A valuable experience in philosophy, literature, and art.
